40335387.review:
Non fatevi ingannare da Puzzle Dimension, dalle immagini sembra uno di quei giochi in cui si comanda liberamente una sfera (come Kororinpa, Monkey Ball o simili) lungo un percorso, invece no, è un puzzle game a caselle in cui al posto della sfera poteva esserci qualsiasi altra cosa.

Detto questo, lo scopo del gioco è, muovendosi/saltando di casella in casella, raccogliere dei fiori e raggiungere l'uscita. Ci sono 100 livelli suddivisi in 10 mondi, nei quali vengono man mano introdotte nuove meccaniche come la sabbia, i teletrasporti, gli interruttori, le caselle scivolose, friabili e via dicendo, con gli ultimi mondi che presentano un mix di un po' tutto quanto.
Non tutte le meccaniche sono ugualmente riuscite, le caselle invisibili ad esempio sono molto noiose perché non si vedono (ovviamente) finché non si è vicini.
I livelli si possono anche ruotare con una telecamera abbastanza rigida, cambiando così l'alto con il basso e dando vita a ingegnose soluzioni in cui buttarsi di sotto per atterrare su una casella dall'altra parte o roba simile, le inquadrature e la prospettiva spesso non sono un granché ed è difficile capire bene.

Oltre a questo c'è anche uno strano sistema di punti con un moltiplicatore che sale in base alla velocità con cui… "depixeliamo" le varie caselle avvicinandoci, cosa che non serve assolutamente a niente tranne a una classifica online che non si vede nemmeno nel gioco, ma solo tramite Steam. 

La curva di difficoltà invece è abbastanza ripida, specie da metà gioco in poi, con diversi livelli in cui la soluzione è una e una sola, non c'è alcuna libertà di movimento o di tentativi: si deve seguire l'esatto percorso pensato dagli sviluppatori dalla prima all'ultima azione, e se per sbaglio si rompe una casella che sarebbe tornata utile più avanti, si deve rifare tutto da capo (posto che ci si renda conto di dov'era l'errore). 
Comunque, gli altri livelli permettono un minimo di improvvisazione, e sono di certo i più riusciti e piacevoli da giocare, anche se finiscono con l'essere tutti abbastanza ripetitivi dopo un po'.

Graficamente fa il suo lavoro ma non è troppo originale (ci sono dei temi aggiuntivi da sbloccare, volendo), e il sonoro è invece composto da un paio di tracce elettroniche stile Megaman per NES, parecchio azzeccate. Come longevità siamo attorno alla dozzina di ore, ma dipende molto da quante mezz'ore decidete di far passare tentando inutilmente di capire la soluzione di alcuni livelli ostici prima di arrendervi e di guardare una guida.
Un titolo discreto per gli appassionati di questo genere di puzzle, che pur diventando frustrante in alcune occasioni regala livelli cervellotici e soddisfacenti quanto basta.

36489678.review:
To start at the end - Puzzle Dimension is easily the best navigation puzzle game I've ever played. Simple as that.

If you look at the abundance of puzzle games created in the last ten years, you'll find plenty in all categories, if you categorize like "navigation", "construction", etc. If you categorize like "2D" and "3D" - well, you'll find hardly any in the latter category. It's not hard to see why - creating good puzzles in 3D is much tougher than in 2D, you need much more serious testing to make sure your wonderful levels don't have some silly loophole that reduces the 15-minute brain-whacking challenge to a 2-minute walkover, and since 3D puzzles are inherently more complicated than 2D puzzles, your game will be much less casual, which seriously reduces your potential audience. So from this aspect, going for a serious 3D puzzle game may look like a silly decision. And what do you call people who make such kind of silly decisions? YMMV, but I call them "heroes of the gaming industry".

Doctor Entertainment took no prisoners with Puzzle Dimension. After the first few levels, it was obvious that the game was created by people with rich craftmanship in puzzle games, people who knew the rulebook well but didn't constrain themselves by it. You're guiding a ball in the game, which can roll (move 1 square), jump (move 2 squares) and later be catapulted (move 3 squares). Your objective is to collect sunflowers on levels that consist of squares, and additionally, you may want to affect (pixelate) all squares for a bonus objective. The squares can connect to each other in a single plane, but they also can connect with 45-degree deviation, which means after two steps you're perpendicular to your previous position, and after four steps you're upside down. The gravity is always related to the square you're on, so you won't fall - but you can jump / roll off, and if there's no square under you, you're dead. This set of rules enables the creatiion of horrenduously complicated levels, and later in the game, there'll be some.

Puzzles start out in a gentle manner, but starting from level 4 or 5, they're not quite obvious. New mechanics are introduced about every five levels - you generally have one simple level to experiment with your new block type, and then there are four more medium headscratchers. That goes on until level 50 (or the first five clusters), then you have two thematic clusters - #6 is called Bends, which showcases the 3D connection method I outlined in the previous paragraph, and gives a teaser of what will come in the last two clusters. Then #8 (revisited) is a kind of remix of earlier levels, big, sprawling and hugely enjoyable puzzles. Non-hardcore puzzle players should consider to stop here...
... because the last two clusters feel more like tactical warfare than a puzzle game. As the conclusion of the game, you get 20 puzzles you need to explore thoroughly, and think about your completion strategy, as you might paint yourself in a corner with your first step already. These levels took quite serious time and effort, but the level of satisfaction gained is massively superior to almost any other game I played. There's no navigation puzzle game that ever came close, and in the entire puzzle "universe", only SpaceChem was better. When I completed the last level (after forty-odd minutes of wrestling with a level that felt like a bona fide roguelike game), it did feel like a huge victory.

Presentation is also worth a few words. The game looks pretty enough with the initial pixelated look, but when you affect the squares, they turn into very nice hi-res blocks. There are four visual themes available (they unlock as you progress), and all of them are beautiful. Sound design is also excellent, with the ball clattering on standard blocks, scraping on ice, or the catapult (spring) blocks making huge noise when launching the ball. The music rounds out the experience nicely.

All in all, it's not too tall to say that Puzzle Dimension is as perfect a navigation puzzle game as it's possible to come close to perfection. I spent more than 15 hours solving its puzzles, and that contained no silly cutscenes and no time wasting. This game stands head and shoulders above the other entrants in its category - if you're looking for a brainy challenge on the PC, this game will surely deliver. Most recommended.

32887438.review:
[b]You might like if:[/b] You like gentle-paced 3D visual/spatial puzzlers.

Kula World anyone?

A very unassuming, yet enjoyable marble-rolling 3D puzzler. I tend to forget it's there, then go back to it and go "oh hey, I forgot this was pretty neat!" - You basically roll around the level with the aim to collect all of the sunflowers to unlock the exit. Why a ball need sunflowers is anybody's guess... But screw it, it looks nice.

The challenge, of course, is in the myriad of tiles introduced along the way. Some collapse after you have used them once, others have spikes that can be deactivated with a switch... and the classic: Ice which keeps you rolling in the same direction - often off the edge of the board.

But this is only half the challenge. When rolling over curved blocks, your orientation and gravity shift with it too, adding a neat dynamic to the game. Sometimes the only way to reach a certain spot above you is to roll around so that it ends up below you, allowing gravity to do its thing. Add into this the regular additions of new blocks, and this makes for a decent puzzler that picks up difficulty pretty nicely - many levels often needing a few attempts to fully crack. I'm not even halfway, so estimate you should be able to get at least a good 10 hours out of this one. Not bad at all for a puzzler.

It looks nice but could perhaps be a bit 'cleaner' / more zen (akin to the likes of Quell, Patterna and Hexcells). Right now it feels like it's not sure what its design should be... particularly in combining HD and retro into some sort of arcade machine. I'm not a big fan of the retro music and sounds, which leaves it feeling a little jarring. That said, the pixelated blocks changing into beautiful HD as you roll near them is an interesting touch and makes for a nice extra to 'paint' the whole level so to speak.

So it's a bit slow to get into and not as engrossing as other head-scratchers out there. But the puzzles are plenty and well-crafted enough to give you something to sink your teeth into. Overall, I'd say it's a well-balanced mix of trial-and-error with sufficient "oh! I think I've spotted how to do it!" to keep it rewarding.

[b]Note:[/b] The metallic ball does not contain an infinity stone. I've tried looking.

Das Spiel ist noch gut.

Das Spiel bietet relativ hübsch designte Level und Rätsel/Puzzle, die auch mal verzwickt sein können.

Allerdings ist meist die Herausforderung nicht etwa der Leveldesign. Könnte ich mir die Level immer aus jeder Perspektive betrachten, wären die Aufgaben relativ einfach.

Die eigentliche Schwierigkeit, einen Level zu lösen, entsteht meist dadurch, dass man, sobald der Level gestartet ist, alles nur noch "über der Schulter" der Kugel sieht, die man durch das Labyrinth steuern muss.

Die Kamera bleibt immer dabei, so dass man durchaus die Orientierung verlieren kann. Wo sind noch mal die Blumen? Wo führt ein Weg zum gewünschten Punkt? Wo war der Ausgang eigentlich noch mal?

Vielleicht ist dies beabsichtigt, mir gefällt es nicht soo gut. Dadurch löse ich manchmal die Rätsel teilweise oder ganz auf gut Glück als durch ausführen einer tollen Idee. Aber es ist auch Knobelei dabei, ohne Frage.

Die unsichtbaren Blöcke, die später hinzukommen, machen es nicht besser. Spätestens da fragt man sich, ob das noch ein Puzzle ist. Denn manche dieser Blöcke werden nicht einmal sichtbar, wenn man daneben steht, so dass man oft auf gut Glück laufen, hüpfen oder fallen muss (und sich möglichst merken muss, wo ein Block war, was bei einem 3D-Puzzle nicht so einfach ist, bei dem s.o. man gerne die Orientierung verliert).

Für mich wertet es das ganze Spiel ab. Das Spiel wird zu einem "Versuch und Irrtum".

Da fällt dann umso mehr auf, dass es keine Undo-Taste gibt (also immer wieder von vorne anfangen) und das ganze Menü sehr dürftig ist: keine Optionen, die Musik dudelt immer in voller Lautstärke, das Spiel ist immer Windowed.

Die Menüsteuerung geht über Tastatur, die Maus ist nur Deko. Es hat eine Weile gedauert, bis ich das gecheckt habe...

Pro & Contra:

+ Teilweise gute Rätsel
+ Gute Grafik
+ Gute Steuerung (der Kugel)

o Wenig Überischt über den jeweiligen Level

- Kein Undo
- Unsichtbare Blöcke
- Keine Optionen

Wertung: 06/10

Mir hat das Spiel nur teilweise gefallen. Ein gewisser Unterhaltungswert ist vorhanden.

26633222.review:
There are about a jillion ways to roll a ball around on Steam, so it really matters how clever the challenges of rolling them are. Puzzle Dimensions starts out simply enough, tasking you with rolling your ornate ball into flowers and portals without plunging into the abyss. But the puzzles amp up quickly, pushing your comprehension of the mechanics to their limits before then introducing new ones. It's a straightforward game with clear mechanics, but succeeds in making the most of them as any good puzzle game does.

Despite being a big proponent of narratives in games, I really appreciate that puzzle games specifically do not require any world-building. This leaves the developers free to craft a wholly unique setting for their puzzles, like the yawning cubist void found here. Your gilded sphere tumbles around on square platforms suspended in this place, turning their appearance from pixellated to high-resolution when it gets near. I have no idea why it does this but it's a neat touch that helps you keep track of where you've been, and also adds the optional challenge of completely de-pixellating a puzzle before solving it.

Solving said puzzles is as simple as collecting all the flowers and reaching the exit gate. Your ball is locked to the grid of squares so don't worry about tight maneuvers or twitch reflexes here, all you need is extensive planning. You can only roll and jump, so everything past that is going to depend on the features of the level and there a lot. I've had to contend with frozen blocks, collapsing platforms, springboards, fire traps, and switch-activated spikes, all just in the first few dozen levels. There's nothing really unique among those hazards admittedly, but they're used in devious combinations that have stumped me more than once.

What is (more) unique is how gravity works. Some platforms are slanted up or down, and when you roll onto them your view rotates to match. This also rotates gravity, and it stays in its new bearing until you traverse another incline. That means if you roll your ball up a 90 degree slope and then hop off the side, the world stays turned on its edge. You'll be using this in the vast majority of levels to collect flowers on the tops, bottoms, and sides of platforms, and some of the transitions can be pretty tricky to find and use.

I keep mentioning it but the real appeal of Puzzle Dimensions is that it's actually pretty hard. Even with just the most basic mechanics in play, the puzzles challenge you to work out optimal paths and three-dimensional solutions. And if you don't struggle to beat the stages, there's a whole scoring and multiplier mechanic tied to de-pixellating platforms that adds an extra layer to puzzle over. Honestly I'm only about halfway into the game but almost every level has me spending minutes just staring at the layout, planning my moves out a dozen rolls in advance.

As solid as the puzzling is, keep in mind that's all you're getting. There are no customization options, no unlocks, no secret stages, nothing but your brain versus a hundred devious puzzles. The graphics at least are incredibly sharp, with bold colors and incredibly detailed textures. The interface is nice and clean as well, and the audio design features rich, immersive effects that bother to get the sound of metal on stone or ice correct. Overall it reminds me a lot of the early titles on Xbox Live Arcade, simple, no-frills games polished to a mirror shine. That's exactly what you're getting here, a clean-cut puzzler that delivers on challenge in a big way.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

26315447.review:
[h1] About Puzzle Dimension[/h1]
[u] Puzzle Dimension[/u]  was a game I got on a whim because it was on sale for 0,62 cents. I figure that there really wasn’t much to lose for a puzzle game like this, and much like my other purchases I get for a really low price, I loved it. It’s a really fun puzzle solving game that really twists the way you think about a puzzle. Like 3D chess, Puzzle Dimension requires you to look at all the right angles before pushing forward.

That’s what I like about puzzle dimension so much, it made me think of other ways to approach a problem. Much of the game relies on camera tricks and thinking in more than one dimension. While the objective is simple, collect all the flowers and leave through the portal, getting there usually isn’t. And while most of the game certainly isn’t as challenging as say Toki Tori, Puzzle Dimension focuses on a different mindset to solve a puzzle. It’s not trying to outwit you, more so it’s making you think differently about solving a problem. While some puzzles in Puzzle Dimension do require a certain order to solve it, if you know how to do all the right tricks and what to leave in and out in order to get to where you want to go, you can solve it however you see fit. As long as you get that marble to the end, it doesn’t matter how many trips you took to get there.

I really don’t have so much complaining, but more of a warning that some puzzles are simply harder than others. While I did the majority of these puzzles without any help, a few select number of them I needed to look up. The game simply didn’t set up a well enough overview for me to see where I was going, and having only a few chances before I messed up again meant I wasn’t always so daring. Such a case could be solved with a rewind button or something like it, but the puzzles were never too trying for that to be a complaint.

All in All Puzzle Dimension is a really nice Game for Puzzle Gamer!

9/10 From Me
[i] Sweep[/i]

25959380.review:
The 3-D aspect of this puzzle game was what drew me to it in the first place and after trying it out I can safely say that I was not disappointed. It adds a new level of critical thinking that is refreshing to see in a space where your traditional puzzle game has become slightly stale. Right from the beginning, Puzzle Dimension forces you to look at each subsequent problem in a new light. The three-dimensional addition is the central concept and everything else flows from it brilliantly, incorporating and weaving itself throughout the entirety of the game. It does this in such a way that it's impossible to get away with not taking advantage of it thanks to the 'bare bones' level designs that are crafted in a very  straightforward manner.

I've played any number of games where the core gameplay mechanics are too far removed from the point of the game itself. So much so, that it becomes detrimental to the finished product, making it awkward and cumbersome. All you can think at that stage is that the developers lost sight of their vision and the all-important "why?" as in, "Why will the consumer (you, me, hardcore gamers, hell, even the guy - or girl - at the coffee shop you pass by every morning) buy this game and why will they continue to play?" In this instance, however, it's very important to state that Doctor Entertainment did not publish one of those, in fact, it is just the opposite.

The levels start off slow and easy to work through, giving you a chance to get sorted out before tossing you in the deep end where they get progressively harder. There's even a fully interactive series of tutorial levels for those of you that are so inclined, that explains everything you need to know. You roll a small sphere around a maze of platforms, collecting the allotted number of flowers before activating a portal that exits each of the levels. They range from simple, flat four directional maps to start, where the only thing to worry about is getting to the end before moving. Soon enough each map moves on to far more complex environments and distorted shapes that implement various traps, frictionless spaces, switches, and blocks that only tolerate a one-time use. This forces the player to plan ahead and make use of what the game is generous enough to provide you.

The keyboard control scheme is simplistic with great camera angles and maneuverability that allows full view of each course so the player can accurately determine the solution for every puzzle. When I saw that full controller support was offered I of course had to test it right away to see how it held up compared to the controls on the keyboard. I was pleasantly surprised that it was both intuitive and easy to use, very similar to its standard counterpart. The transition between the two peripherals is smooth and seamless; the only question that remains is which feels more comfortable to each particular user, so it's just a matter of which one you prefer.

Even though the gameplay, while marvelously complex in thought and execution remains at its core very simplistic, my biggest critique about this game has to be the soundtrack. My issue isn't even that it's blatantly bad or anything of that nature because if you listen to the BGM as a standalone composition without playing the game than its actually pretty good; at least enough to make the game relaxing and enjoyable, for the first few worlds anyway.

With the level of concentration required in the later part of the game, one of two things will happen. The music will become somewhat more of a distraction than a pleasing accompaniment. You will find yourself lowering the volume more and more until eventually the sound effects and all associated music tracks are off completely.

Either that or you will be so engrossed in trying to solve the puzzles that it will just fade into the background until it becomes nothing more than a soft whisper that you can't really hear anyway, which was the case for me at least. I mean... it's not terrible, but it isn't the greatest either. The tracks just seem to sit in the middle of the road like a destitute hitchhiker waiting for the right person to come along and pick them up. A touch more subtlety would have worked wonders in this case.

For the achievement hunters among you this game may pose a different sort of challenge, especially for the last two:

The "Unpixelat0r" achievement requires you to unpixelate every single block in the game. This may not seem like much but can add an extra layer of challenge to the game because in many cases you will have to either backtrack or add or account for this variable when calculating your route through the level.

"Total Score: Gold." You can only unlock this one if you have a total score of at least 50,000 by the end of the game. Here, you will have to understand how the scoring system works in order to get a handle on that 50k. If you enjoy Puzzle Dimension enough to play through multiple times than you don't have to worry. You can do an initial play through to get a better understanding of the scoring system and formulate some kind of strategy. If on the other hand, you don't think you will be able to finish it more than once, than I suggest you familiarize yourself with this before you get started to avoid having to redo any sections unnecessarily.

I find that in Puzzle Dimension's attempt to be innovative, which it succeeds at, by the time I reached the end it was also quite overdone. The developers did themselves a disservice in that regard, which is a shame because once I started the first few levels it was hard to put down. For a game that boasts one hundred levels, I'm inclined to think that the game is about three to four worlds too long and just like another puzzle game that comes to mind - Chip's Challenge - I'm not afraid to say that I find myself in one of those situations where the mindset that less is more wins out. If it was shortened just a little bit and things spread out, redistributed, then I would say this game could be a 10/10 without hesitation. As it stands, though, Puzzle Dimension is a fantastic, well-rounded puzzle game, so I'm going to give it a solid 8/10 and call it a day.

23562526.review:
[h1] Puzzle Dimension	[/h1]

Given that most people appear to be unable to successfully navigate the average high street pavement without severe difficulty, a game which demands proficiency in 3D spatial visualisation might well be enough to frazzle the withered synapses of a large portion of the populace.

It all starts off innocuously enough. Tasked with rolling a ball around a series of three-dimensional environments, you simply have to pick up all the sunflowers and head to the exit gate. That is, until you find yourself dealing with a gameworld where gravity is a relative concept, and the surfaces you can roll onto dictate where is up, and where is down.
5

Puzzle Dimension: Insane in the membrane.

Resplendent in a beautiful pixellated retro theme with a backdrop of chiptune bleeps, Puzzle Dimension sees you plotting a careful path over hazard-strewn tiles, activating pressure plates and bounding over one-way lanes, fiery traps and crumbling tiles while trying to pick the increasingly elusive sunflowers. This isn't the way Paul Weller imagined it.

Curving ramps lead you up and over to the underside of the playing area, which causes initial confusion, but with patient trial and error you start to rewire your brain's understanding of 3D space and the rules that govern it. Before you know it, you're navigating the winding maze-like 3D structures with aplomb, unpicking their devious secrets.

With places on the worldwide leaderboard up for grabs, completing each of the 100 levels is only part of the challenge. Could Doctor Entertainment have come up with the Trials of puzzle gaming? Buy it now, rewire your ailing brain and find out.

[b] 9/10	[/b]

21128226.review:
Un puzzle game pas cher avec énormément de contenu. Vous contrôlez une boule se déplaçant sur des cases dans un univers en trois dimensions. La gravité s'aligne toujours avec la case sur laquelle vous vous trouvez ce qui force à constamment réfléchir en trois dimensions. De plus, de nombreuses cases ont certains effets sur votre boule qu'il faut prendre en compte. (La glace vous fait glisser jusqu'à ce que vous tombiez sur une case où vous pouvez vous arrêter, le sable vous force à sauter d'une case pour vous en sortir, etc...) L'objectif est de récupérer un certain nombre de fleurs puis d'atteindre la sortie. Les niveaux sont assez petits mais combinent les différentes mécaniques de façon à avoir des énigmes vraiment intéressantes et qui deviennent rapidement assez difficiles.

Le jeu a néanmoins deux défauts assez rageants:
Premièrement, les contrôles sont loin d'être parfait. Si vous allez trop rapidement il est très facile de partir dans la mauvaise direction parce qu’on n’a pas assez tourné la caméra. Sachant qu'on est constamment entouré de vide, une erreur de direction entraîne très souvent de tomber et devoir recommencer le niveau.
Deuxièmement, il n'y a aucune fonction pour annuler une action comme on peut en trouver dans de nombreux autres puzzle game. Si vous faites une erreur vous devez tout recommencer dès le début. Associé aux problèmes de contrôles ça m'a causé pas mal de frustration.

Au final, si vous arrivez à passer outre ces problèmes et que vous cherchez un puzzle game pas cher avec beaucoup de contenu et de challenge je recommande vraiment ce jeu.

20883430.review:
Puzzle Dimension to gra logiczna z elementami zręcznościowymi od studia Doctor Entertainment, w której naszym zadaniem jest doprowadzić kulke przez różne i ciekawie skontstruowane łamigłówki do bramy, oczywiście najpierw trzeba zebrać wszystkie kwiatki z planszy i nie dopuścić, żeby kulka wleciała w nicość, tyle o rozgrywce. Gra jest bardzo ciekawa i to na tyle, że jest podobna do gry z pierwszego Playstation o nazwie Kula World, wystarczy obejrzeć gameplaye z obu gier, żeby powiedzieć, że Puzzle Dimension wygląda jak nowa wersja gry Kula World. Wróćmy jednak do naszej recenzowanej gry. Plansze są ciekawe i zmyślnie skonstruowane, z początku wydaje się, że będzie to krótka i prosta popierdółka, a tu co rozdział dalej tym trudniej i jesteśmy zmuszeni przyjrzeć się planszy dokładnie oraz przemyśleć swoje ruchy, z początku wystarczy tylko odpowiednio dotrzeć do kwiatków, później trzeba się głowić jak to ugryść, z kąd i gdzie. Oczywiście rozdziałów jest 10 i wszystkie po 10 poziomów, niektóre są czasami prostsze od poprzednich, a czasem o wiele trudniejsze. Opiszmy teraz kolejną rzecz.

Oprawa audiowizualna prezentuje się bardzo dobrze, grafika jest nawet ładna(grałem na full detalach), w grze mamy do wyboru 4 motywy, które oczywiście odblokowujemy wraz z naszymi postępami, ale są bardzo ładne i zmieniają wygląd całej planszy, muzyka też jest na poziomie i przyjemnie jej się słucha, oczywiście jest ich 23, jedna w menu oraz po dwie przypisane do jednego rozdziału, z czego jedna to normalna wersja, a druga to samo tyle, że puszczona w wersji jak z gier 8-bitowych, które zamieniają się podczas zmiany planszy czy restartu planszy i tyle można powiedzieć w tym temacie.

Teraz aspekt techniczny gry. Podczas całej rozgrywki nie spotkałem się z ani jednym błędem czy bugiem bądź glitchem, nawet się nie zaciął, gra szybko się ładuje i jest płynna. w sumie po wymaganiach można stwierdzić, że żaden komputer nie będzie miał problemu z odpaleniem tej gry, chyba że gra na Amidze to wiadomo, a ze sterowaniem też większych problemów nie miałem, według mnie przyjemnie się gra na padzie w tą giereczke

Podsumowując:
+Ładna grafika i kilka motywów
+Przyjemna i fajna muzyka
+100 coraz to zmyślniejszych i trudnych łamigłówek
+Ciekawy gameplay
+Gra o niskich wymaganiach, która pozwoli się włączyć nawet na starych komputerach
+Zero problemów z błedami czy bugami
+Płynne działanie gry
+Sterowanie jest ok
-Nie ma podpowiedzi, więc musisz sam myśleć jak to ukończyć (minus na siłe, po prostu ta gra nie ma minusów)
Moja ocena to 10/10, gra jest wymagająca i ma ciekawy gameplay, tyle się nagłowiłem w tej grze, myślałem że wymiękne, ale udało mi się ją nawet wymaksować, jeżeli szukacie wyzwań i nie boicie się pogłówkować to polecam to grę kupić i w nią zagrać bez żadnej pomocy w postaci filmików z gier czy innych podpowiedzi, gra na wiele godzin.

+ graficamente gradevole e rilassante
+ musichetta giusta
+ gameplay originale ed intrigante
+ quindi ottima idea di base
+ voglia di andare avanti 
+ voglia di risolvere quel puzzle che non riesci a risolvere.
Tuttavia te ne freghi e domani non ci pensi più, perchè:
- comandi scomodi, complessi e frustranti
- telecamera scomoda, opprimente e frustrante
A volte perdi una partita difficilissima, quando sei quasi arrivato alla fine, dopo mezzora di ragionamenti e salti mortali, non sai manco tu come hai fatto ad arrivarci a quel punto, perdi la partita solo perchè fai un pasticcio tra i comandi. Sbagli pulsante, per colpa di quella fottuta telecamera mongoloide, mentre guardi a destra e sinistra, guardi in alto e in basso, che non ci capisci una mazza, mentre perdi 8 minuti a girare la rotellina lentissima per ingrandire la visuale, finalmente hai capito cosa fare, sai dove andare, però schiacci il pulsante sbagliato e fai un clamoroso tuffo nel cesso e perdi la partita per una cavolata del genere!!!!
Insomma è come quando giocando a scacchi dal vivo, sbatti contro il tavolino e rovesci la scacchiera.
Insomma basta! 
Mi sono rotto di ricominciare le solite partite con questo schifo di controlli.
Quando aggiusterete i comandi proverò a proseguire.
Perchè il gioco tutto sommato è carino se comprato a pochi spiccioli.
Voto complessivo 5/10
Inoltre voglio criticare il Tutorial perchè risulta inutile e palloso:
- dice cose ovvie, tipo insegnante di sostegno per i down
- invece non spiega le cose importanti, ad esempio come funziona il sistema punti.

Worth the $3!

19185226.review:
壁に張り付いて花を集めるアクションパズルゲーム。

グラフィックと音楽が綺麗だがゲーム性はクソ。
ほとんどの場合、すぐに解法がわかっていてもなかなかクリア出来ない。

まず操作性が劣悪。
デフォルトでは簡単なジャンプがオンになっていて、狙った方向にジャンプしやすくなっているが、
狙ってない方向にもジャンプしやすくなるので、勝手に変な方向に飛んで死んだり、その場ジャンプして床が割れて死んだりする。
氷の床からジャンプして来てスペース押したまま割れた床に乗った時点で詰み。
必ず最初に簡単なジャンプはオフにしましょう。

簡単なジャンプをオフにしても、見にくい位置にある氷のパネルや針、透明な床などプレイを何も考えてない配置のせいで
ジャンプのタイミングや位置、方向を事前に慎重に考えたり、瞬時の判断をしなきゃならなかったりする。
大体、ジャンプしないと死ぬパネルとジャンプしたら死ぬパネルが混在してるのがひどすぎる。
常に画面をぐるぐる回して先を予測しなきゃならないのに、針パネル、割れる床、スイッチなどが見づらすぎる。
さらに、透明な床に至っては見回しても見えない。ふざけるな。

以上の理由により、答えがわかっても操作が上手く出来なくて死ぬことが圧倒的に多い。

ステージ構成も良いステージはあるけど、ほとんどのステージは無意味に割れる床を置いたり無意味に針を置いたり。
とにかく雑。めんどくさいだけで、答えは簡単なのに操作ミスでプレイヤーを殺そうとする。

また、クリアランプを緑にするためには全てのパネルに近づかなきゃいけない。
つまり、攻略に必要のない無駄においてあるパネルを、わざわざ遠回りして踏まなきゃいけない。
まるで作者のクソみたいな想定解を無理やりやらされてるようで嫌になります。
普通最短でゴールするのがいいんじゃないの？

しかも、踏んでないパネルがわかりづらい。
ひと目でわかるようにしてくれればいいのに、ゴールしてから踏んでないパネルがあることに気づいたりすると
また最初からやり直し。本当にイライラする。

そして何が一番の問題かというと、リトライボタンがない。
答えがとっくにわかってるのに何度も何度も操作ミスして、エスケープ押してリトライを押すのが本当にめんどくさい。
と思ったら、リトライボタンを設定出来た。なんでデフォルトで設定されてないの？

じゃあ一手戻すボタンもあると思ったら見つからない。
だから完璧な解法をわかっていても、１回操作ミスしただけで全て水の泡で最初からやり直し。
これパズルゲームじゃないの？一手戻すボタンがあると何か作者に不都合があるの？

つまり作者はパズルで勝負出来ないんですよ。
わかりづらい配置や操作ミスを誘発して、何度も何度もやらせることを目的としてステージを作ってる。
しかも無駄に100ステージあってボリュームだけはあるからタチが悪い。

これは本当に本当のクソゲーです。
これをおすすめしてる奴は他のパズルゲームをやったことがない。
パズルゲームがやりたいならこれじゃなくぜひEnglish country tuneをやりましょう。


細かいところ
チュートリアルで時間制限がないって言ってるくせに、実際は時間がスコアに関係する。その説明はどこにもないしわかりづらい。
マウスでの操作が変で、カーソルの移動と変更が両方ホイールに割り当てられてて、
オプションでホイール回すと設定がめちゃくちゃになる。
非アクティブにしてブラウザとか開いてるといつの間にか全然違うステージにいることがある。

19074508.review:
Game Information

Puzzle Dimension, is a PP game, that is developed and published by Doctor Entertainment AB.

 PP - Puzzle Platformer.

Game Visuals

I want to mentioned that the visuals in the game is well done. The visuals can be adjusted in the game's option menu.

Game Audio

I want to mentioned that the audio in the game is well done even if it is simplistic and somewhat repetitive. The audio can be adjusted in the game's option menu as well.

Gameplay

There is no difficulty game modes to choose from. Each of the puzzles has their own difficulty.

It is recommended to play the tutorial puzzle levels to understand the puzzles' functions.

There are four different themes to unlocked by playing the game to collect the flowers.

There are roughly a hundred puzzles to solve, they are divided up to ten clusters, each has different puzzles. The first clusters comes automatically unlock. While the remaining clusters are locked. And they require "x" amount of flowers before they can be unlocked.

There is no reset button in this game. Plan out the solution before completing the puzzles. If an error has been then the puzzle has been restarted. There is an opportunity to replay all the puzzles for a better score.

There are twenty-five different achievements that can be unlocked from playing the game. Each of these achievements does come with some requirements that needs to be completed before they can be unlocked.

Miscellaneous

Final thoughts: I have the game enjoyable to certain extent. The replay value this game is low. I would recommend this game but not at the game's full price value.

16759512.review:
Let me start my review with the negatives:
1. THE FREE DEMO YOU CAN DOWNLOAD GIVES ABSOLUTELY NO INDICATION OF SOME OF THE GAME'S FEATURES. For instance, I was pleasantly surprised to find that 16:9 resolutions are actually available in the full version, including 1080p and anti-aliasing. The demo only had some really silly resolutions, meaning it was still playable, but didn't fit my screen. The full version also has its own achievement system and themes (visual styles), which are unlocked after you've collected enough flowers for each one. 
2. The controls are keyboard only, which gives  great control of the ball, but takes some getting used to! 
Now the positives:
1. There's no time limit, which means you can take your time figuring out the solution for each puzzle. 
2. The "playing field" is made up of blocks, which all have different properties. The cracked block, for instance, disappears after one use, while the ice block makes the ball roll forward (and potentially roll off, unless it encounters another block!). There are about 10 different types of blocks in total, so collecting the flowers needed to complete each level can sometimes be a real challenge!
3. The game can be started from any level you've previously unlocked, and once you've figured out the solution, each level takes about one and a half minutes. This makes for a perfect casual title.
4. The game is an absolute joy to play if you like pretty graphics and imaginative puzzles!
Score: 12 out of 10

Приятная озвучка, оригинальный и запоминающийся дизайн слегка остужают дымящиеся мозги. Job well done. It went on discount, I noticed it has a demo! Tried it, was very pleased with a proper assortment of settings in the options menu, and navigation is smart, fluid and everything looks well-polished. Noticed the somewhat chiptuney music and was immediately captivated by the simple-yet-beautiful assembler-demo-like visuals. I think I only played half of the demo content before my decision to buy.
The game is centered around sunflowers! What more could you ask for?!

You can take your time, and once you have figured a puzzle out, you can try doing it in record time, getting extra score with multipliers and such. It's implemented in the normal game mode. Elegantly done.

The game concept reminds me a bit of The Bridge (which came later, so it might have been inspired by this, who knows?).

The only thing that bothers me a little is the artificial difficulty-raising because of the camera. Apparently getting the optimum view in any moment is intended to be part of the challenge.

Primeira analise de 2015, viva!

Fala ae meu povo! Beleza? Olha eu aqui de volta enchendo o saco! Hoje vou falar um pouco sobre o Puzzle Dimension, esse magnífico jogo de puzzle em 3D, não é legal? Hahaha

Puzzle Dimension provavelmente é um produto unico, devido ao seu desenvolvimento músical, que, junto com os cenários, tudo aparenta estar em perfeita harmonia. Graficamente possui um aspeto Retro. Não que o seja, mas faz uso de ideias como a construção de estruturas através de pixeis, em semelhança ao que acontece em Minecraft ou 3D Dot Game Heroes, para se assemelhar ao estilo. O mesmo acontece com a banda sonora, na íntegra constituída por sons Retro. Em contrapartida os cenários de fundo apresentam um estilo mais futurista, com ambientes coloridos e dinâmicos.
Objetivo principal – coletar todos os girassóis espalhados pelo cenário, e o melhor, não tem limite de tempo. Outra coisa, você movimenta uma esfera, comandos simples. Caso compre não desista, vá até o fim!

Se vale a pena, vale. Boa diversão! E Feliz Ano Novo!

13194670.review:
It's a decent game.
To start with its negatives: it has none. I could argue that the overall theme doesn't quite connect (why flowers, and why are they in 8-bit?) and the music gets annoying after a while, but those are minor gripes. Same with the controls: it uses the arrows, shift+arrows (for turning the camera), c (to toggle freemode view) and space (jump). A gamepad is preferred.

The good part is in the level design. As mentioned in another review, if you've played Kula world/Roll Away/Kula Quest: this is sort of a remake of this. But where that game threw you right in the deep end with all sorts of gravity twists, this one gradually introduces you to the concept.

I didn't play that long yet (barely an hour), but I can say it was worth the money. It's not an AAA-title...but it isn't aiming to be one. :-)

13136542.review:
Challenges you to think; solving increasingly complex puzzles in three dimensions. Up can be down, and down and be up which can be disorienting from time to time. It does add great depth to the levels & used with strong effect by some excellent level designs.

Ten zones with ten puzzle levels in each. I found that the difficulty fluctuated somewhat between zones and levels, sometimes dealing a relatively easy one you complete in mins, to others that had me scratching my head for a long time. Saying this, overall you do still feel the levels gradually get harder as you proceed further through the game relying more on your spatial awareness & reflexes.

Big Picture friendly, the controls are simple to learn and most forgiving (that's not to say you won't fall to your doom a multitude of times regardless lol). Unlike the free movement in [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/18300/]Spectraball[/url] for example, [b]Puzzle Dimension[/b] works off a grid layout, moving you one square at a time in the direction your camera is facing. Each surface may be different though, and you need to calculate their effect into your moves as well as the layout of the level. These increase the complexity [i](gradually introduced)[/i] and includes such modifiers as ice [i](can't stop on square)[/i], fire [i](can stop, but can't stay long)[/i], spikes [i](jump over)[/i] or limited use squares that disintegrate! There are many more.

The high quality environments have a bit of a surreal feel, with the levels themselves floating in a virtual void. They look great! I would recommend putting v-sync on for those with higher end graphics cards as the game seems to run my card full throttle making it run hot. Sounds have a very 'arcadey' feel to them and are pretty good too.

There really isn't much that detracted from my experience, although it can get frustrating on some longer and more complex levels to have to start from the very start again [i](there is no mid-level checkpoints)[/i]. You almost have to memorise the entire run and practice and practice [i]and practice[/i] some more to complete it. Adds to the difficulty, most certainly, but sometimes results in shorter sessions later in the game. Think an easier difficulty with checkpoints on longer/complex levels could help keep more casual puzzle players engaged and progressing through.

All-in-All, [b]Puzzle Dimension[/b] is an underrated title, offering excellent value for the amount of well-designed levels you get. Impressive overall quality from graphics & sound, to menus, to gameplay. Well worth checking out for those who like to flex their mental muscles!

9975904.review:
If you are looking for a top-notch puzzle game that cleverly uses three-dimensional space, Puzzle Dimension is definately the game for you. The puzzles are mindboggling and each one is both clever and unique. You're goal is simple: traverse the puzzle to collect all the sunflowers and get to the goal without falling infinitely, being spiked, roasted alive, or otherwise incapacitated.

The game creatively adds new mechanics as the levels get more and more difficult, and each add a whole new level (or should I say, a new set of levels, for each mechanic has its own group of levels focused on intorducing and using it) to the already deep puzzler that it is. The levels complement the mechanics well, and they are all challenging and fun to solve. I've finished about two thirds, and it never stops dropping new ideas and challenges on you.

The graphics are simple, and they do the job well. There are four options to choose from (all showcased in the trailer), so you can change how the game looks to your liking. In each texture, you can still easily tell the difference between the different types of tiles, even if it does take a little getting used to if you just switched. Music is also quite catchy with a nice retro-ish style to it.

The biggest issue with this game is the controls. This is a console port, and boy do you know it after a minute of rolling the ball around. Arrow keys for movement, okay. WASD for six-directional camera, I'll live. The jumping however, is very clunky. Once you hit space to jump, you cannot change the direction you are going. This means you have to time your jumps between the time you press an arrow key to the time you roll off the edge of the block. This certainly isn't a dealbreaker, and I stand by my reccomendation wholeheartedly, but this is easily my biggest gripe with the game. That and invisible platforms.

All in all, Puzzle Dimension is certainly worth the low price of admission, and if you can get it at one of the many times it is on sale, it's a steal. It is easily one of the best puzzle games I have played and one that uses 3-D space in ways most puzzle games don't bother to explore. At the very least try the demo. It will show you if you can stand the controls and how much this game has to offer.

8183300.review:
Puzzle Dimension es un juego en 3D que sirve para ejercitar la parte de tu cerebro relacionada a la visualización espacial. El objetivo es girar una bola dorada para recolectar diversos girasoles dispersos por el escenario y entonces activar el portal de salida de la fase.

Tal vez parezca simple saber el objetivo del juego antes de probarlo, pero puedes tener la seguridad de que tendrás grandes dificultades para descubrir la mejor estrategia para recolectar todos los girasoles que necesitas.

El primer paso para ir especializándote en Puzzle Dimension es entender cómo funcionan los movimientos de la bola. En pocas palabras, cada flecha presionada hace que ella se mueva un cuadro – nunca menos que eso. Sin embargo, dependiendo del bloque que tocas, existen otras reacciones posibles.

Por ejemplo, hay bloques que se rajan cuando te pones al lado de ellos y se rompen cuando le pasas por encima. Otros, en vez de eso, accionan un horno. Además de esos, existen también los que te hacen quedarte trabados (es necesario saltar para salir), deslizar (cuidado con el abismo) y saltar tres cuadrados. Por otro lado, existen también los que dependen de la activación de un botón para entrar en acción (desaparecer y expulsar clavos).

Aparte de aprender a rodar adecuadamente – o sea, siempre llevar en consideración el tipo de bloque donde te encuentras -, también es necesario aprender a saltar. Esa acción es bastante simple y es usada con frecuencia para evitar algunos peligros. Ahora, imagina tres cuadrados alineados: 1,2 y 3. Si ruedas, vas de 1 a 2. Al saltar, vas del 1 al 3.

Frecuentemente la cámara incomoda bastante por estar posicionada en un mismo ángulo. Para cambiar eso, existen dos técnicas que puedes usar. Una de ellas consiste en presionar la tecla Shift y usar las flechas direccionales del teclado para alterar permanentemente el ángulo de visión. La otra es, cuando usas la tecla C para entrar en el modo de visualización y ver de lejos cuáles son las posibilidades de movimiento – para después volver al ángulo inicial de la cámara.

8057831.review:
Puzzle Dimension est un jeu surprenant tant par son originalité que par sa facture graphique qui mérite d'être joué au moins une fois, si ce n'est que par simple curiosité.

Puzzle Dimension mélange des éléments de réflexion et d'action dans un tout très harmonieux. Le but du jeu: recueillir toutes les fleurs d'un niveau avant de sortir par le portail. Mais c'est loin d'être gagné. Malgré son apparence simple, les casse-têtes deviennent vite très complexes et requièrent une excellente capacité de visualisation. Les mouvements se font à l'aide des flèches du clavier. On fait avancer la balle une tuile à la fois à l'aide des flèches pour «dépixéliser» les tuiles à l'allure rétro sur son chemin et leur redonner un look moderne. Il est aussi possible de sauter par dessus une tuile avec la barre d'espacement pour éviter les trous ou les obstacles rencontrés en chemin. La prise en main est très aisée au début; on passe rapidement du menu principal aux tutoriaux, puis au jeu lui-même. Par le fait même, les menus présentent immédiatement les options à débarrer en jouant, autant les séries de niveaux suivants que des thèmes de jeu. Fait à noter, ces thèmes supplémentaires changent complètement l'aspect du jeu et permettent donc de choisir son ambiance favorite. Les sons et la musique rappellent les jeux d'arcade des années 70 à 80 ce qui, combiné aux tuiles pixelisées, donne une allure très particulière aux niveaux lorsqu'on y entre.

Le comportement de chaque tuile individuelle est fort simple. C'est leur combinaison qui apporte toute sa profondeur au jeu. La difficulté des casse-têtes augmente très rapidement et non seulement les tuiles forment des obstacles vicieux, mais leur disposition dans l'espace est tout aussi importante et exploite pleinement les trois dimensions. Si le déplacement de base ne fait que rouler la bille sur la surface des tuiles, il n'est pas rare de devoir sauter ou se jeter dans le vide pour aller rejoindre une plateforme plus basse et éventuellement passer de l'autre côté d'une tuile déjà explorée. Le nombre de paramètres à prendre en considération pour déterminer le chemin à prendre pour compléter un niveau offre d'excellents exercices mentaux. Heureusement, il est possible de mettre le jeu en mode pause à tout moment pour prendre le temps d'observer la situation sous tous ses angles.

Le jeu offre deux façons de jouer et permet de passer de l'une à l'autre à sa guise. La première est tout simplement de résoudre les casse-têtes un à un pour débloquer les suivants. La seconde façon de jouer est de passer les niveaux le plus rapidement possible afin d'obtenir un plus haut pointage et ainsi débloquer des thèmes et niveaux supplémentaires pour pouvoir en profiter plus vite. Ce défi supplémentaire n'est pas nécessaire mais permet de visiter les niveaux avec un nouvel objectif en tête - celui de la performance - une fois qu'ils ont été résolus. Puzzle Dimension est fortement conseillé aux amateurs du genre. La seule ombre au tableau est l'absence d'éditeur de niveau, ce qui réduit la rejouabilité une fois qu'on a passé tous les niveaux au moins deux fois. Malgré tout, le jeu offre de multiples dimensions à explorer et jouit d'une superbe exécution.

7618786.review:
Puzzle Dimension was a game I got on a whim because it was on sale for 79 cents. I figure that there really wasn’t much to lose for a puzzle game like this, and much like my other purchases I get for a really low price, I loved it. It’s a really fun puzzle solving game that really twists the way you think about a puzzle. Like 3D chess, Puzzle Dimension requires you to look at all the right angles before pushing forward.

That’s what I like about puzzle dimension so much, it made me think of other ways to approach a problem. Much of the game relies on camera tricks and thinking in more than one dimension. While the objective is simple, collect all the flowers and leave through the portal, getting there usually isn’t. And while most of the game certainly isn’t as challenging as say Toki Tori, Puzzle Dimension focuses on a different mindset to solve a puzzle. It’s not trying to outwit you, more so it’s making you think differently about solving a problem. While some puzzles in Puzzle Dimension do require a certain order to solve it, if you know how to do all the right tricks and what to leave in and out in order to get to where you want to go, you can solve it however you see fit. As long as you get that marble to the end, it doesn’t matter how many trips you took to get there.

I really don’t have so much complaining, but more of a warning that some puzzles are simply harder than others. While I did the majority of these puzzles without any help, a few select number of them I needed to look up. The game simply didn’t set up a well enough overview for me to see where I was going, and having only a few chances before I messed up again meant I wasn’t always so daring. Such a case could be solved with a rewind button or something like it, but the puzzles were never too trying for that to be a complaint.

Aesthetically the game looks beautiful and the music has a nice chip-tune beat too it. The standard settings of the game don’t really ruin the puzzle solving and provide for a better standing of what you are doing. Although a lot of the newer tiles you unlock throughout the game do provide to be far too distracting compared to the first one.

Final Thoughts:

Puzzle Dimension is a different kind of puzzle game; it’s not really one to challenge your mind as it is to challenge your view on how to solve problems. Aesthetically the game looks great, but when using the non-default skins the game can be a bit more distracting. The game can also be a bit of a trial and error run, but it never gets too mind numbing to turn the game off. Overall Puzzle Dimension was an enjoyable puzzle experience that any fan of the genre should play.

2091671.review:
It doesn't really come as a surprise to know that the designer of Puzzle Dimension co-founded the development team of Kula World for the PlayStation.

The game play is very much like Kula World's. You navigate a ball around various stages picking up things (flowers, in this game's case) in order to move to the next level. 

The levels are all quite smartly made, introducing new concepts and obstacles as you progress through the game in a timely manner. Being able to roll around on more than just the top of some levels is another neat feature from Kula World.

Overall, Puzzle Dimension is one of those nicer puzzle games on the market. Nothing overwhelmingly difficult, but provides enough challenge (and a decent aesthetic for an indie game) to make you feel good about yourself after beating a few levels.

It's definitely worth getting for the price of £1.99, especially if you enjoyed Kula World.

6105609.review:
とりあえずの感想：
グラフィックやBGM,各種設定などゲーム周辺の部分がかなりハイレベル。
肝心のパズル部分も面白く、分かりやすいがハマると楽しめる。
なお、完全日本語対応で、丁寧な日本語で説明してくれる。

グラフィックはアンチエイリアスや影表現にも（無駄に）対応。凄く綺麗。
BGMはチップチューン風で、ファミコン時代に聞いたようなメロディが豊富。
ゲーム設定は解像度や音量設定、コントローラコンフィグにも対応していて、日本語にも対応。

パズル部分は、自機となるボールを操り全ての花を回収したのち、ゴールに到達するという内容。
足場となるパネル１マスを基準に移動し、粘着テープのように斜面も貼りついて進める。

特徴的なのは、斜面を転がるとマップ全体が回転し、普通では落ちてしまう裏面へと行ける事（分かりにくい人はマリオギャラクシーというゲームを想像）。
この要素のおかげで、一見すると単純なマップもかなり複雑なパズル性を持っている。
また、各ステージごとに特殊なパネルが用意されていて、一度通ると壊れてしまうパネル等、プレイヤーを飽きさせない要素も練られている。

パズル好きなら、この値段では買っとくべき。

1438320.review:
This is a fantastic Puzzle game. Having finally gotten around to beating the final level I can say that I was thoroughly challenged throughout.

Have you ever played a game called Roll Away? Nevermind that. You control a ball. You can turn, roll one square, or hop over one space. The premise is simple. But then it all goes wonky when you realize that rolling over an edge might put you on a tilted platform. And then gravity shifts so that you don't fall off. And then you do it again. All of a sudden, what was up is down and what was down is up. Have you got that? The end space is still in the same place. And the keys (or in this case Sunflowers) are also in the same place. Maybe that made them easier to get. Maybe you goofed and need to turn right side up again. Either way, the puzzle deepens as you lose your sense of direction.

The only real lacking feature is a level editor. It would have been a blast to play levels that even the developers couldn't come up with. But I wouldn't hold my breath. This game isn't new. That fabled level editor is never coming out. But alas, the levels that they do give you are solid for the price they charge. $3 at the time of writing (but actually on sale so $0.75). I would say that's easily worth the cost for one of the most interesting puzzle games I've seen to date.

I just wish there was more of it to play. Maybe if they make a ton of sales the developers will make another game that does include a level editor. Looking forward to their next one.

Gran juego independiente descubierto por casualidad al comprar el "Swedish Indie Pack". Básicamente consiste en recorrer un escenario en tres dimensiones, recoger unas flores y dirigirse a la salida. Por supuesto todos los caminos son en forma de puzle.

Puede parecer que es un tipo de juego ya muy visto pero aporta varios detalles muy novedosos:

1. La posición de la cámara cambia según dónde te sitúes. Por ejemplo, lo que antes estaba arriba pasa a estar abajo. Esto exige una buena visión espacial, aunque la dificultad es progresiva y se van pillando los diferentes trucos.

2. La estética es en tres dimensiones pero pixelada. Cuando pasas al lado de los distintos objetos del escenario su forma cambia y pasa a ser el clásico render.

3. Es fantástico el amplio abanico de obstáculos y objetos que ofrece. Sin duda el creador del juego le ha echado mucha imaginación.

Recomiendo empezar con el tutorial para saber cómo mover la cámara y así ver bien el escenario.

This is an excellent title, and sells for only three dollars. No reason to not have it in your collection. If you're nervous about committing three dollars, there's also a demo.

Mechanics involve sliding a ball along the puzzle map to collect sunflowers -- doing so opens the exit gate for each map. The difficulty and complexity gets ramped up for each set of worlds because of new block-types that get introduced to maps: crumble tiles; ice tiles, which force you to continue moving in a certain direction if you touch them; sand tiles, from which you cannot roll away (only jump); switch tiles, which toggle the on/off state of spike tiles in the map; hidden blocks, which become visible when you stand next to them; spring tiles; and so forth.

The devs included retro 8-bit music to the game which sounds quite nice and fits the theme a bit. No map editor, though *sad*

1321111.review:
'Puzzle Dimension' is a (wait for it) puzzle game (bet you didn't see that coming) in which you play a ball rolling around a landscape collecting things and trying to get to the exit.

Yes, before anyone brings it up, reminiscent of 'Kula World'.

The game has more up it's sleeve than balls however.

The game looks beautiful, the landscapes are very good looking and you can tell alot of effort was put into them. The gameplay is smooth, the controls fluid, and the sound track is very much fitting.

The object of the game is to roll your ball over sunflowers (scattered throughout the level) and to reach the exit. All while 'converting' tiles from a 'pixelated' form to a 'realistic' form.

The game starts easy and gradually becomes more difficult as new platforms are added and more convoluted puzzles befuddle your mind.

'Eurogamer' gave this game 9/10 and I am inclined to agree. This game deserves a well-earned 9/10

Have a look at the demo.

229806.review: Slick production and a nice change of pace from action games. Plan routes carefully and complete the dozens of maps. Rewards for fast times and complete de-pixelization/use of the maps. Will challenge your ability to strategize and plan ahead, but doesn't get out of hand (until the final levels anyway) and you can do it at your own pace. Nice graphics, good physics, and great music/audio. Excellent indie title.

1451812.review:
This is a neat little marble puzzle game. It starts off pretty simple with you just rolling and jumping on platforms to collect the flowers, and gets more complicated with blocks you can only land on once, blocks that fling you a couple spaces in the direction you happened to be travelling, etc.

There's no time limit, which I love. The only timer seems to be for score multipliers. The achievements are very straight forward and do-able, and the game is easy to play without getting boring because the puzzles stay challenging enough.

If you need a time-waster game that you can turn off whenever you want and not lose a ton of progress though a level, this is a great game to choose.

3341209.review: オススメパズルゲーム。「前後左右に玉を転がしてマップ上の花を全て集め、ゴール地点にたどり着く」という至ってシンプルなゲーム。ただ実際には「ジャンプしか出来ない」「一度しか踏めない」などといった特殊なマスがあったり、かなり立体的な面があったりと、そこいらのFlashゲームにはない魅力は十分にありました。音楽もかなり雰囲気が良く、10面につき1曲しかないBGMでも飽きることは特にありませんでした。配信にてプレイし、4回で合計16時間でようやくクリア出来ましたが、全100面中一番悩んだ面でも1時間弱だったので、「詰んだ！」とはならない程度の頭の体操レベルだと思います。

287524.review: I love puzzle games and this is one of the classic styles of 'you're a ball, collect things and go to the exit' puzzles. Only with a twist. Several twists in fact as the environment becomes more and more complex and confusing with each puzzle, each one seemingly more impossible than the last. But the controls are simple and easy to master (joypad ftw) and a bit of lateral thinking soon sees you loosing off a great sigh of relief as another level falls beneath your mental prowess. Very rewarding.

1092828.review: Another really great puzzle game. This one's more of a straight puzzler. There's only really one way to solve them. Unlike Cogs the difficulty curve is just perfect with a few puzzles each world to introduce you to a new concept and then the rest expounding upon that knowledge. The graphics are gorgeuos and it even has Steam achievements (for you, Homemaster!) Grab it on sale if it's not your thing but I've easily gotten 15 hours out of it just completing the puzzles (not unpixelating everything and getting higher scores.)
